page_analysis.text_content:
Projections
Architectural relief
features such as bay
windows are pleasant
additions to a house
design and are
encouraged. If they
meet certain design
criteria they do not
count toward gross
floor area.
Bay windows
Bay windows that meet the design criteria below are considered to be decorative
architectural features and do NOT count toward gross floor area.
Design criteria for bay windows that do not count:
• Bottom of teature must be at least 18" above the floor joists
• Exterior supports must be teatures like corbels and/or brackets
rather than solid walls
• At least 50% of the surface is glass
Fig 13 Bay windows
2' max. from bay window
surface to facade surface
(Typical all)
Note: Bay windows that ex-
tend higher than the struc-
ture's roof are considered
to be dormers and count to-
ward gross floor area.

visual_elements.description:
Figure 13: Bay windows. This figure illustrates five different bay window configurations (labeled A through E) and indicates whether they count towards gross floor area based on specific design criteria. Each illustration shows a cross-section of a bay window attached to a building facade. 
- Illustration A: Shows a bay window with its bottom at least 18 inches above the floor joists and supported by corbels. It has a dimension line indicating '2' max. from bay window surface to facade surface (Typical all)' and another indicating '18" min. from top of floor to bottom of baywindow structure'. This configuration 'Does NOT count'.
- Illustration B: Shows a bay window where the floor joists extend into the bay window structure. This configuration 'Counts because floor joists continue into the bay window'.
- Illustration C & D: Shows two bay windows, one with an angled exterior skirt wall and another with a straight exterior skirt wall. Both are labeled together as 'C & D' and 'Count because of exterior skirt wall (angled or straight)'.
- Illustration E: Shows a bay window where the glass surface appears to be less than 50% of the total surface area. This configuration 'Counts because the surface is not at least 50% glass'.

technical_specifications.parameter: Minimum height of bay window bottom above floor joists
Minimum glass surface percentage for non-counting bay windows

subheadings: Design criteria for bay windows that do not count:

additional_notes: The term 'teature' appears to be a typo and should likely be 'feature' in the bullet points under 'Design criteria for bay windows that do not count'.

qualifiers.text: Bay windows that meet the design criteria below
Bay windows that extend higher than the structure's roof

conditions.text: Bottom of feature must be at least 18" above the floor joists
Exterior supports must be features like corbels and/or brackets rather than solid walls
At least 50% of the surface is glass
Bay windows that extend higher than the structure's roof
floor joists continue into the bay window
the surface is not at least 50% glass

logical_relationships.expression: IF (c1 AND c2 AND c3) THEN Bay windows do NOT count toward gross floor area.
IF (c4) THEN Bay windows are considered to be dormers AND count toward gross floor area.
IF (c5) THEN Bay window Counts toward gross floor area (as per illustration B).
IF (c6) THEN Bay window Counts toward gross floor area (as per illustration C & D).
IF (c7) THEN Bay window Counts toward gross floor area (as per illustration E).

execution_sequence.action: Evaluate if bay window meets all criteria for not counting towards gross floor area.
Evaluate if bay window extends higher than the structure's roof.
Evaluate if floor joists continue into the bay window.
Evaluate if the bay window has an exterior skirt wall (angled or straight).
Evaluate if the bay window surface is not at least 50% glass.
